The six non-Buddhist teachers always expound the Dharma and teach sentient beings, saying:
'If one can respectfully pay homage to the six directions in the morning, then one will increase one's lifespan and wealth.

The western land belongs to the god Varuna. Those who make offerings to him, Varuna will then protect and assist them.ğŸ”½The northern land belongs to the god Kubera. Those who make offerings to him, Kubera will then protect and assist them.
The lower land belongs to the fire god. Those who make offerings to him, the fire god will then protect and assist them.
The upper land belongs to the wind god. Those who make offerings to him, he will also protect them.'
World-Honored One!
Are there such six directions in the Buddha's teachings?
Good man!
In my Buddha's teachings, there are also six directions, namely the six pÄramitÄs.
The east is the pÄramitÄ of giving.
Why is it so?
Because it is the initial emergence, it is the cause and condition for the emergence of the light of wisdom.
The east belongs to the minds of sentient beings. If sentient beings are able to make offerings to the pÄramitÄ of giving, they will then increase their lifespan and wealth.
The south is the perfection of morality.
Why is it so?
The perfection of morality is called the right. If one makes offerings, one will also obtain the increase of longevity and wealth.
The west is the perfection of patience.
Why is it so?
The west is called the rear, because all evil dharmas are discarded in the rear. If one makes offerings, one will obtain the increase of longevity and wealth.
The north is the perfection of vigor.
Why is it so?
The north is called superior to all evil dharmas. If one makes offerings, one will obtain the increase of longevity and wealth.
The nadir is the perfection of meditation.
Why is it so?
Because one is able to contemplate the three evil destinies correctly. If one makes offerings, one will also obtain the increase of longevity and wealth.
The zenith is the perfection of wisdom.
Why is it so?
Above refers to the unsurpassed, because of being unsurpassed. If one makes offerings, one will then be able to increase one's lifespan and wealth.
Good man!
These six directions belong to the mind of sentient beings, not like the teachings of the six non-Buddhist teachers.
Who is able to make offerings to the six directions in this way?
Good man!
Only bodhisattvas are able to make offerings.
World-Honored One!
Why is one called a bodhisattva?
The Buddha said:
Because one attains enlightenment, one is called a bodhisattva;
Because one has the nature of enlightenment, one is called a bodhisattva.
World-Honored One!
If one is called a bodhisattva because one has attained enlightenment, then before making offerings to the six directions, why is one called a bodhisattva?
If one is called a bodhisattva because of one's nature, who has this nature?
One who has this nature is able to make offerings, but one who lacks this nature is unable to make offerings!
Therefore, the TathÄgata should not say:
That the six directions belong to the minds of sentient beings.
Good man!
It is not because of attaining enlightenment that one is called a bodhisattva.
Why is it so?
One who attains enlightenment is called a buddha, and one who has not attained enlightenment is called a bodhisattva;
It is also not because of having the nature that one is called a bodhisattva.
Good man!
All sentient beings do not have the nature of enlightenment, just as sentient beings do not have the nature of humans or gods, the nature of lions, tigers, wolves, dogs, and so forth;

In the present world, because of the combination of good karmic causes and conditions, they attain the bodies of humans and gods, and because of the combination of unwholesome karmic causes and conditions, they attain the bodies of animals such as lions and so forth.
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Because of the combination of good karmic causes and conditions, they give rise to the mind of enlightenment, and are therefore called bodhisattvas.
If there are those who say that all sentient beings have the nature of a bodhisattva, this is not so.
Why is it so?
If there were a nature, then one should not cultivate good deeds, make offerings to the six directions,
Good man!
If there were a nature, then there would be no initial mind or mind of retrogression;
It is because of immeasurable good karmic causes and conditions that the mind of enlightenment arises, which is called the nature of a bodhisattva.
Good man!
There are sentient beings who accept the practice of non-Buddhist paths, but do not delight in the inverted teachings of non-Buddhist scriptures, so they give rise to the mind of enlightenment;
Or there are sentient beings who dwell in a place of tranquility, and give rise to the mind of enlightenment due to inner good causes and conditions;
Or there are sentient beings who observe the faults of birth and death, and give rise to the mind of enlightenment;
Or there are sentient beings who see evil and hear evil, and give rise to the mind of enlightenment;
Or there are sentient beings who deeply understand their own greed, anger, delusion, stinginess, and jealousy, and give rise to the mind of enlightenment in order to rebuke them;
Or there are sentient beings who see the five supernormal powers and spiritual attainments of non-Buddhist practitioners, and give rise to the mind of enlightenment;
Some sentient beings wish to know whether the world has an end or not, and therefore give rise to the mind of enlightenment;

Some sentient beings, having seen and heard of the TathÄgata's inconceivable [qualities], give rise to the mind of enlightenment;ğŸ”½Some sentient beings, out of compassion, give rise to the mind of enlightenment;
Some sentient beings, out of love for sentient beings, give rise to the mind of enlightenment.
Good man!
There are generally three kinds of the mind of enlightenment, namely, inferior, middling, and superior.
If it is said that sentient beings definitely have a nature, how can it be said that there are three kinds?
A sentient being's inferior mind can become a middling mind, a middling mind can become a superior mind, and a superior mind can become a middling mind.
Because sentient beings diligently cultivate immeasurable wholesome dharmas, they are able to increase;
If they do not diligently cultivate, they will regress and become inferior.
If they cultivate well and progress, they are called non-regressing; if they do not cultivate and progress, they are called regressing.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Because they always cultivate goodness for the sake of all sentient beings without limit, they are called irreversible.
If it were not so, it would be called reversible. Such bodhisattvas would then have a mind of regression and a mind of fear.

If they always cultivate wholesome dharmas for the sake of all sentient beings and attain irreversibility, therefore I predict that they will soon attain supreme perfect enlightenment in this great stage of joy.
Good sons!
The three kinds of enlightenment have no fixed nature;
if they had a fixed nature, then those who have already aroused the mind of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas would not be able to arouse the mind of enlightenment.
Good sons!
It is just like how the assembly of monks has no fixed nature. The three kinds of natures are also like this.
If there are those who say that there is a fixed nature, they are called non-Buddhists.
Why is it so?
Because the non-Buddhists have no cause and effect, like the god ÄªÅ›vara who is neither a cause nor an effect.
Good man!
Some people say that the nature of a bodhisattva is like the definite presence of gold in a stone. Through skillful means and conditions, it becomes usable as gold;
The nature of a bodhisattva is also like this. This is what the Brahmins say.
Why is it so?

The Brahmins and others always say that Nyagrodha seeds have Nyagrodha trees, and that eyes have fire and stone. Therefore, the Brahmins have no cause and no effect. The cause is the effect, and the effect is the cause.
Nyagrodha seeds are complete with Nyagrodha trees, which should be known as the cause and effect of the Brahmins.
This meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
Because the cause is subtle and the effect is coarse.
If it is said that there is definitely fire in the eyes, the eyes will be burned;
If the eyes are burned, how can they see?
If there is stone in the eyes, the stone will block the eyes;
If the eyes are blocked, how can they see again?
Good man!
As the Brahmins say:
Existence is existence, nonexistence is nonexistence;
Nonexistence does not give rise to existence, existence should not cease.
If it is said that gold exists in stone, gold does not speak of existence, existence does not speak of gold.
Good man!

Because of causes and conditions, there is then combination. Because of the combination of conditions, the originally nonexistent later exists. Like what the brÄhmaá¹‡a says, nonexistence is forever nonexistent.
What does this mean?
Gold combined with mercury, the gold then disappears. If it is said to exist, it should not disappear.
What does this mean?
If it is said that sentient beings have the nature of a bodhisattva, this is called non-Buddhist, not the Buddha's way.
Good man!
It is like the fact that because of the combination of stones and conditions, there is the use of gold. The nature of a bodhisattva is also like this.

Sentient beings have thoughts, which are called the mind of desire. Using such desire, the causes and conditions of good karma give rise to the mind of enlightenment. This is then called the nature of a bodhisattva.
Good man!
It is like sentient beings who first do not have bodhi but later come to have it. Nature is also like this, first not having and later having. Therefore, it cannot be said to definitely exist.
Good man!
Seeking great wisdom is called bodhisattva.

Desiring to know the true reality of all dharmas, having great adornments, having a firm mind, delivering many sentient beings, and not sparing one's body and life, this is called the bodhisattva practicing the Great Vehicle.
Good man!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
1. Those who regress, and 2. Those who do not regress.
Those who have already cultivated the karma for the thirty-two marks are called those who do not regress;
If they are not yet able to cultivate, they are called those who regress.
There are also two kinds:
1. Those who have left the household life, and 2. Those who remain in the household life.
The bodhisattva who has left the household life upholds the eight grave precepts and is completely pure. This is called not regressing;
Householder bodhisattvas who uphold the six grave [precepts] and are replete with purity are also called non-retrogressive.
Good sons!
The merit and virtue obtained by non-Buddhists through severing desires surpasses the merit and virtue of all beings in the desire realm;
SrotÄpannas surpass all non-Buddhist heterodox views;
Saká¹›dÄgÄmins surpass all SrotÄpannas;ğŸ”½AnÄgÄmins surpass all Saká¹›dÄgÄmins;
Arhats surpass all AnÄgÄmins;
Pratyekabuddhas surpass all Arhats;
Householders who give rise to the bodhi mind surpass all Pratyekabuddhas.
It is not difficult for renunciant practitioners to give rise to the bodhi mind, but for householders to give rise to the bodhi mind, this is called inconceivable.
Why is this?
Because householders are bound by many evil conditions.
When laypeople give rise to the bodhi mind, from the Four Heavenly Kings up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha gods, all greatly rejoice and say:
We have now obtained a teacher of humans and gods.
Chapter on Giving Rise to the Bodhi Mind UpÄsaka Precepts SÅ«tra, Chapter 2 on Giving Rise to the Bodhi Mind SubhÅ«ti said:
World-Honored One!
How do sentient beings give rise to the bodhi mind?
Good man!
One gives rise to the bodhi mind for two reasons:
First, to prolong one's lifespan; second, to increase one's wealth and possessions.
There are also two other reasons:
First, to ensure that the lineage of bodhisattvas is not cut off; second, to eliminate the suffering, afflictions, and karma of sentient beings.
There are also two other reasons:
First, to contemplate the great suffering and lack of benefit one will experience in immeasurable lifetimes;
Second, even if there are innumerable buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, none of them can save me, so I must save myself.
There are two more things:
First, to do all kinds of good deeds; second, to not lose them after doing them.
There are two more things:
First, to surpass the karmic rewards of all humans and gods; second, to surpass the karmic rewards of all two vehicles.
There are two more things:
First, to undergo great suffering in order to attain the path of enlightenment; second, to attain immeasurable benefits.
There are two more things:

First, to deeply contemplate that the buddhas of the past and future as numerous as the sands of the Ganges are all like my body; second, to deeply contemplate that enlightenment is a dharma that can be attained, and therefore to give rise to the resolve.
There are two more things:
First, to contemplate that although those in the six stages may have wavering minds, they are still superior to all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas;
Second, it is because they diligently seek the unsurpassed fruit.
There are two more things:
First, wishing to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation; second, wishing to enable sentient beings' liberation to surpass the fruits attained by non-Buddhists.
There are two more things:
First, not abandoning any sentient beings; second, abandoning all afflictions.
There are two more things:
First, to end the present suffering and distress of sentient beings; second, to prevent the future suffering and distress of sentient beings.
There are two more things:
First, to end the obstacles to wisdom; second, to end the obstacles to the bodies of sentient beings.
Good man!
There are five things in giving rise to the mind of enlightenment:

First, being close to good friends; second, ending the mind of anger; third, following the teachings of the teacher; fourth, giving rise to a compassionate mind; fifth, diligently cultivating and practicing.
There are also five things:

First, not seeing the faults of others; second, even if one sees the faults of others, not being regretful; third, having attained wholesome dharmas, not giving rise to arrogance; fourth, seeing the good deeds of others, not giving rise to jealousy; fifth, regarding all sentient beings with the thought of a single child.
Good man!
A wise person, having given rise to the mind of enlightenment, is then able to destroy the fruits of evil karma like Mount Sumeru.
A wise person gives rise to the mind of enlightenment for three reasons:

First, seeing the sentient beings of the five turbidities in the evil world; second, seeing the inconceivable spiritual powers and penetrations of the TathÄgata; third, hearing the Buddha TathÄgata's eight kinds of wonderful sounds.
There are also two things:

First, clearly knowing that one's own body has suffering; second, knowing the suffering of sentient beings as if one were experiencing the suffering oneself, and in order to end that suffering, it is no different from one's own.
Good man!

If there are people who can give rise to the bodhi mind, one should know that these people can pay homage to the six directions and increase their lifespan and wealth, unlike what is proclaimed by non-Buddhists.
Chapter 3: Compassion, from the UpÄsaka Precepts SÅ«tra. SubhÅ«ti said:

translated: I speak to sentient beings of either one cause, or two causes, or three causes, or four causes, or five causes, or six, seven, up to twelve causes.
Speaking of one cause refers to the cause of birth.
Speaking of two causes refers to the cause of birth and the cause of realization.
Speaking of three causes refers to afflictions, karma, and the vessel.
The four causes refer to the four great elements.
The five causes refer to the five future [links of dependent origination].
The six causes refer to the six causes as explained in the sutras.
The seven causes refer to those explained in the Lotus Sutra.
The eight causes refer to the eight present [links of dependent origination].
The nine causes refer to those explained in the Great City Sutra.
The ten causes refer to those explained for the upasaka Ma-nan.
The eleven causes refer to those explained in the Wisdom Seal Sutra.
The twelve causes refer to the twelve links of dependent origination.
Good man!

All contaminated dharmas have immeasurable and boundless causes, and all uncontaminated dharmas have immeasurable and boundless causes. Because the wise wish to fully understand this, they give rise to the mind of enlightenment;
therefore the Tathagata is called the Omniscient One.
Good man!
All sentient beings give rise to the bodhi mind, some with a cause of birth, some with a cause of understanding, some with a cause of birth and understanding.
You should now know:
The cause of birth is great compassion;
Because of this compassion, one is able to give rise to the mind. Therefore, the compassionate mind is the cause of birth.
World-Honored One!
How does one cultivate the compassionate mind?
Good man!
The wise deeply see all sentient beings drowning in the ocean of suffering in birth and death. In order to rescue them, compassion arises.

Furthermore, seeing that sentient beings do not yet have the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, great compassion, and the three kinds of mindfulness, how can I cause them to be fully endowed?
Therefore, compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing that sentient beings, though full of resentment and poison, still have thoughts of intimacy, therefore compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing that sentient beings are confused on the right path and have no guidance, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings lying in the mud of the five desires and unable to emerge, yet still indulging, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings always bound by wealth, possessions, and wives and unable to let go, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings giving rise to arrogance because of their appearance and life, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings giving rise to thoughts of intimacy due to being deceived by bad friends, like the six masters, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings falling into the realm of birth and existence, experiencing various sufferings, yet still delighting in attachment, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings creating unwholesome evil karma of body, speech, and mind, experiencing much suffering as a result, yet still delighting in attachment, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings thirsting for the five desires like a thirsty person drinking salty water, therefore compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings who, although wishing to seek happiness, do not create the causes of happiness;
Although they do not enjoy suffering, they happily create the causes of suffering;
Desiring to experience heavenly bliss, they do not fully observe the precepts, and therefore compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing sentient beings who, in the absence of self and possession, give rise to the notion of self and possession, compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing sentient beings who lack a fixed nature, wandering in the five destinies, compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing sentient beings who fear birth, old age, and death, yet still create karma that leads to birth, old age, and death, compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing sentient beings who experience the suffering of body and mind and create karma again, compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing sentient beings who suffer from the separation of loved ones but do not end their attachments, compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing sentient beings who dwell in the darkness of ignorance, not knowing how to light the lamp of wisdom, compassion arises.
Furthermore, seeing sentient beings who are burned by the fire of afflictions but are unable to seek the water of samÄdhi concentration, compassion arises.
I also see sentient beings creating immeasurable evil for the sake of the five desires, and therefore give rise to compassion.
I also see sentient beings knowing the suffering of the five desires, yet seeking them without rest, like a starving person eating poisoned food, and therefore give rise to compassion.
I also see sentient beings dwelling in a bad world, encountering tyrannical rulers, suffering much distress, yet still being heedless, and therefore give rise to compassion.
I also see sentient beings revolving in the eight sufferings, not knowing how to eliminate such causes of suffering, and therefore give rise to compassion.
I also see sentient beings hungry, thirsty, cold, and hot, not having mastery over themselves, and therefore give rise to compassion.
I also see sentient beings violating the precepts, and will receive the retribution of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals, and therefore give rise to compassion.
I also see sentient beings not having mastery over their appearance, strength, lifespan, peace and security, and eloquence, and therefore give rise to compassion.
I also see sentient beings with incomplete faculties, and therefore give rise to compassion.
Also, seeing sentient beings born in border regions, not cultivating good dharmas, therefore compassion arises.
Also, seeing sentient beings in a world of famine, their bodies emaciated, mutually robbing and stealing, therefore compassion arises.
Also, seeing sentient beings in a world of warfare, harming each other, evil thoughts increasing, to experience immeasurable suffering as retribution, therefore compassion arises.
Also, seeing sentient beings encountering the Buddha's appearance in the world, hearing the teaching of the pure nectar-like Dharma unable to accept and uphold it, therefore compassion arises.
Also, seeing sentient beings believing in evil friends, never following the teachings of good and wise advisors, therefore compassion arises.
Also, seeing sentient beings having many treasures and wealth, unable to give in charity, therefore compassion arises.
Also, seeing sentient beings farming and planting, engaging in commerce and trade, all suffering, therefore compassion arises.
Also, seeing sentient beings who do not love and care for their parents, siblings, spouses, children, servants, relatives, and clans, therefore compassion arises.
Good man!
The wise should contemplate the bliss of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as if it were the suffering of hell, shared equally by all sentient beings, therefore compassion arises.
Good man!
When one has not yet attained the Way, making such contemplations is called compassion;
If one has attained the Way, it is then called great compassion.
Why is it so?
Before attaining the Way, although one makes such contemplations, the contemplations all have boundaries, and sentient beings are also like this;
Once one has attained the Way, both the contemplations and sentient beings are all boundless, therefore it is called great compassion.
Before attaining the Way, the mind of compassion moves and changes, therefore it is called compassion;
Once one has attained the Way, there is no more movement or change, therefore it is called great compassion.
Before attaining the Way, one is not yet able to save all sentient beings, so it is called compassion;
After attaining the Way, one is able to greatly save and deliver, so it is called great compassion.
Before attaining the Way, it does not accompany wisdom, so it is called compassion;
After attaining the Way, it accompanies wisdom, so it is called great compassion.
Good man!
The wise cultivate compassion, and although they are not yet able to end the suffering and distress of sentient beings, they already have immeasurable beneficial matters.
Good man!
The six perfections all take the compassionate mind as the cause of their arising.
Good man!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, those who have left the household life, and second, those who remain in the household life.
Cultivating compassion while having left the household life is not difficult;
Cultivating compassion while remaining in the household life is difficult.
Why is this?
Because those who remain in the household life have many unfavorable conditions.
Good man!
If laypeople do not cultivate compassion, they will not be able to obtain the precepts of an upÄsaka. If they cultivate compassion, they will then obtain them.
Good son!
Monastics can only perfect the five perfections, but cannot perfect the perfection of giving. Laypeople can perfect it.
Why is this?
Because they give everything at all times.
Therefore, laypeople should first cultivate compassion. If they cultivate compassion, one should know that such a person can perfect morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom.

If they cultivate the compassionate mind, they can give what is difficult to give, endure what is difficult to endure, and do what is difficult to do. For this reason, compassion is the root of all good dharmas.
Good son!

If a person is able to cultivate such a compassionate mind, know that this person can destroy evil karma like Mount Sumeru, and will soon attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. The little wholesome karma created by this person will yield fruits and rewards like Mount Sumeru.
Chapter on Liberation, Scroll 4 of the UpÄsaka Precepts SÅ«tra, Chapter on Liberation Good sons!
If good men and good women cultivate compassion, know that these people will attain the liberation of the essence of all dharmas.
SubhÅ«ti said:
World-Honored One!
What is meant by essence? What is essence?
Good sons!
It refers to body, speech, and mind.
This body, speech, and mind are obtained through skillful means.
Skillful means are of two kinds:
First, hearing with the ears; second, contemplation.
There are also three kinds:
First, giving; second, upholding precepts; third, being well-versed [in the teachings].
SubhÅ«ti said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, one attains the factors of liberation through three skillful means. Are these three skillful means fixed in number?
No, it does not.
Good man!
Why is it so?
There are people who, although they have made immeasurable offerings with immeasurable wealth to immeasurable people over immeasurable eons, are still unable to attain the factors of liberation;
there are people who, in a single moment, offer a handful of flour to a single beggar, and are able to attain such factors of liberation.
There are people who, over immeasurable eons and in the presence of immeasurable Buddhas, uphold the precepts, and are still unable to attain the factors of liberation;
there are people who, for a single day and night, uphold the eight precepts and are able to attain the factors of liberation.

There are people who, over immeasurable eons and in the presence of immeasurable Buddhas, uphold and recite the twelve divisions of the scriptures, and are still unable to attain the factors of liberation;
there are people who, by merely reading a single four-line verse, are able to attain the factors of liberation.
Why is it so?
Because the minds of all sentient beings are not the same.
Good man!

If a person cannot single-mindedly contemplate the faults of birth and death and the peace and bliss of nirvana, such a person, even if they are generous, uphold precepts, and have much learning, will still not be able to attain the factors leading to liberation.

If one is able to be disgusted with the faults of birth and death and deeply see the merits, virtues, peace, and bliss of nirvana, such a person, even if they are of little generosity, uphold few precepts, and have little learning, will be able to attain the factors leading to liberation.
Good man!
Those who attain this Dharma, in the three periods of time - when the Buddha appears in the world;
when the pratyekabuddhas appear;
If neither of these two is present, when the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven speaks of liberation - this person, having heard, attains the factors leading to liberation.
Good man!

When I first generated the mind of enlightenment in the past, I did not see buddhas or pratyekabuddhas at all. I heard the Pure Abodes heaven speak of the Dharma of liberation, and upon hearing it, I immediately generated the mind of enlightenment.
Good man!
Such a Dharma cannot be attained by the gods of the desire realm.
Why is it so?
Because of their heedlessness.
It also cannot be attained by the gods of the form realm.
Why is it so?
Because they lack the three skillful means.
It also cannot be attained by the gods of the formless realm.
Why is it so?
Because they lack body and speech.
The essence of this Dharma is body, speech, and mind.
The people of Uttarakuru also cannot attain it.
Why is it so?
Because they lack the three skillful means.
This liberation can be attained by three kinds of people, namely Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas.

If sentient beings encounter a good and virtuous friend, they can transform the liberation of Å›rÄvakas and obtain the liberation of pratyekabuddhas, and transform the liberation of pratyekabuddhas and obtain the liberation of bodhisattvas;
The liberation and factors of liberation obtained by bodhisattvas are irreversible and indestructible.
SubhÅ«ti said:
World-Honored One!
What is the meaning of the Dharma teacher being able to skillfully distinguish such people as having the factors of liberation?
What is the meaning of such people not having the factors of liberation?
Good man!
Such Dharma is obtained by two kinds of people, namely, lay and ordained.

These two kinds of people, with utmost sincerity, listen to the Dharma, and after listening, uphold it. Hearing of the suffering of the three evil destinies, they are frightened, with hairs standing on end, tears flowing uncontrollably, strictly observing precepts, not daring to violate even minor precepts. Know that such people have the factors of liberation.
Good man!

The non-Buddhists attain the concentration of neither perception nor non-perception, with a lifespan of innumerable eons. If they are unable to attain the factors of liberation, one should consider such people to be hell beings.
